solution_01_data_basics/02_proportion/02_list_proportion_between_v2

video

First, it helps to sort the data. \[\text{sort}(\mathbf{x}) = 12, 13, 13, 13, 14, 14, 14, 15, 18, 19\]

You could use R to sort the data:

sort(c(13,12,14,18,15,14,14,13,19,13))
##  [1] 12 13 13 13 14 14 14 15 18 19

You could also use a spreadsheet. Import the table into a spreadsheet. Then, highlight the column of measurements and use Sort function.


  1. (ANS=1) The proportion of measurements between 11.5 and 19.5 is 1. \[\text{prop}[11.5<\mathbf{x}<19.5]=1\]
  2. (ANS=0.9) The proportion of measurements outside 14.5 and 15.5 is 0.9. \[\text{prop}[\texttt{NOT}(14.5<\mathbf{x}<15.5)]=0.9\]
  3. (ANS=0.8) The proportion of measurements closer than 3.5 cm from 14 cm is 0.8. \[\text{prop}\left[\big|\mathbf{x}-14\big|<3.5\right] = 0.8\]
  4. (ANS=0.6) The proportion of measurements farther than 1.5 cm from 15 cm is 0.6. \[\text{prop}\left[\big|\mathbf{x}-15\big|>1.5\right] = 0.6\]
  5. (ANS=2.5) You can guess and check until you find a half-integer that satisfies the equation. It turns out that \(r = 2.5\) satisfies the equation, because \[\text{prop}\left[\big|\mathbf{x}-17\big|<2.5\right] ~=~ 0.3\]
  6. (ANS=1.5) You can guess and check until you find a half-integer that satisfies the equation. It turns out that \(r = 1.5\) satisfies the equation, because \[\text{prop}\left[\big|\mathbf{x}-16\big|>1.5\right] ~=~ 0.9\]
